abstracts.cdata!:
Assessment of the project's overall
            outcomes is complex. In terms of timely implementation of
            components, the project did not give a satisfactory
            performance. If delays and cancellations are ignored, the
            project outcomes for the State components covering 85
            percent of project costs are satisfactory. In summary,
            sectoral policy objectives were generally achieved;
            institutional development objectives were only partially
            achieved; physical objectives were generally achieved in the
            States schemes but only partially in the central schemes;
            and the poverty reduction objective and gender concerns have
            been adequately achieved. Key lessons learned include:
            Project appraisal should take a closer look at institutional
            capacity relative to project complexity and identify
            institutional and systemic weaknesses that delay project
            implementation. The Expenditure Finance Committee (EFC) memo
            should discourage the labor ministry from being selective in
            component approval, provide some flexibility during
            implementation, take into account normal price escalations
            and currency fluctuations, and prefer the use of SDRs. The
            project should be more decentralized and flexible in
            selecting trades, procuring equipment, and developing
            curriculum. Participatory approaches could improve project
            ownership and outcomes. Frequent changes in senior
            implementation staff should be avoided and technical
            assistance provided. Land acquisition and architectural
            design of buildings should start before negotiations.
